section.title: HamQSLer
section.para: HamQSLer is a program for designing and printing amateur radio QSL cards. HamQSLer is the most feature rich QSL design and print program available today. Its capabilities include:

listitem.para: One-sided landscape card;
Resizable and movable background image, or no background image;
Add resizable and movable secondary images;
Resizable, movable, and editable text fields, including callsign, name and QTH, and a salutation by default;
User settable default text for the following fields so that you do not have to enter for each card you design:
callsign;
name and QTH; and,
salutation
Add resizable, movable, and editable text fields;
Macros that can be inserted into text fields;
Variable number of QSOs in the QSOs box;
Choice of date formats in the QSOs box;
Choice of printing bands or frequencies in the QSOs box;
Choice of including or not including a QSL column in the QSOs box;
User settable defaults for the QSOs box:
confirmation text;
column headers;
frequencies to be displayed when none provided in QSO;
text placed in QSL column; and,
font used to print the QSOs box text.
Supports import of ADIF 2.0 files, including support up to version 2.2.7;
QSOs to be printed may be selected by:
band,
mode;
date and time;
QSL sent and received value;
individual selection; or,
any combination of the above.
QSOs to be printed may be sorted by date and time, callsign or by QSL bureau;
Print multiple cards per page;
Support for commonly available perforated cardstock;
Print "blank QSO" cards so that pages are not wasted; and,
Automatic checking for program updates.

section.title: Why Another QSL Design And Print Program
section.para: There are a large number of computer programs available for printing QSL cards. A cross-section of these include:

listitem.para: QSO logging programs that print cards, or labels for affixing to preprinted cards;
Programs that print labels for affixing to preprinted cards;
Programs that print a single QSO on each card; and,
Logging programs that provide DDE capability for import into Microsoft Word or similar programs for printing cards.

section.para: They are all limited in one way or another and therefore have never satisfied my requirements. Specifically,they either provide limited or no design capability, or only print one QSO per card. They also tend to waste cardstock because they stop printing when the card for the last QSO is printed on the page. I wanted more!

Have I succeeded? Well, many of my goals have been satisfied. Each future release of this software will provide greater capabilities and let me at least come closer to my desired goal of providing the best QSL design and print program that money can't buy.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: In this tutorial, we will create and save a simple card, load QSOs from an ADIF file and select the QSOs to print, and finally, print the QSOs.
The first steps are to become familiar with the HamQSLer splash screen , become familiar with the main program window, and then set a few user preferences.

section.title: The HamQSLer Splash Screen
section.para: When the HamQSLer program starts, it performs a number of functions:

listitem.para: Displays the splash screen;

Performs a number of initialization steps including initializing the HamQSLer directory and its contents, creating the user preferences if it doesn't exist, and checking if a new version of the program or data files are available.
Destroys the splash screen and displays the main program window.

If you cannot determine the cause or solution of the problem fromÂ the messages displayed on the splash screen, see the Program Initialization and the Splash Screen chapter.

The function tabs select the view that is displayed in the Work Area. The QSOs tab shows the loaded QSOs for which cards may be printed. The QSOs panel, shown in the image below, contains 5 QSOs that have been loaded from an ADIF file, the Sort Cards Panel, and the QSOs filters tabs. There are four QSOs filters tab, each of which contain filters for selecting QSOs. The four filters are:

With no card item (text, background or other image, or the QSOs Box) selected, the properties panel is empty. When a card item is selected, the properties panel shows the properties for that card item. section.title: Setting a Few User Preferences
section.para: Now that you are familiar with the main program window, we will start to create a sample QSL card. But before we begin with the actual design of the card, we must first set a few user preferences.
Select the User Preferences... menu item from the Edit dropdown menu. This will display the User Preferences dialog shown in the image below.

section.title: Select the Default Text Font
section.para: Click on the triangle to the left of "TextItems", or double-click on the "TextItems" text to open the expander. Now click on "Default Text Font to display the Default Text Font panel. See the image below.

The dropdown list contains a list of every font that is registered on your computer. Select the font that you want as the default font for all text items. Don't worry, the font can be set individually for each text item when you design your card. Sample text in the selected font face is shown in the text block below the dropdown.
You can click on the Apply button to save this change, or wait until you have made additional changes before applying them.

section.title: Set Your Default Callsign
section.para: Click on "Callsign Text" under the TextItems expander to display the Callsign Text item panel. There is a text editing field that contains the text "MyCall". Change "MyCall" to the callsign that you most often use. Do not click the Macros button; we will discuss this later when we look at the salutation.
The image below shows what you should see at this point, replacing VA3HJ with your callsign.
Either click on the Apply button to save this change, or wait until more changes have been made.

section.title: Set Your Name and QTH
section.para: Click on "Name and QTH Text" under the Text Items expander to display the Name and QTH item panel. In that panel, click on My Name and QTH to open that expander. The expander contains a text editing field containing the text "My Name and QTH". Change this text to your name and mailing address, using the Return key at the end of all except the last line. Again, do not click the Macros button.
The image below shows what you would see at this point if you had entered my name and address.

section.title: Set Salutation
section.para: Click on the Salutation Text item under the TextItems expander to display the Salution panel. This panel contains only the Macros button. Click on this button to open the Text and Macros dialog. The dialog should look like this:

The first Static Text groupbox contains an edit box with the text "Thanks for the QSO" in it. The Static Text groupbox at the bottom of the dialog similarly contains an edit box with the text ". 73," in it. The groupbox in the middle, labeled "Count Macro", contains fields for editing the content of a CountMacro. Macros are beyond the scope of this tutorial; the CountMacro is simply mentioned here because we will discuss it later while we design a sample card. Click the Close button to close the dialog.
Macros are discussed in the Macros chapter.

section.title: Select the Default QSOs Box Font
section.para: Open the QSOs Box expander and click on the "Default QSOs Box Font" text to open the Default QSOs Box Font panel. This panel is similar to the Default Text Font panel. Select the font to display QSO information in; this font may be the same or different than the default text font.
All user preferences are discussed in the Setting User Preferences chapter.
Now that we have set a number of user preferences, it is time to design your first card.

section.title: Creating a Default Card
section.para:
To create a card, click on the Cards dropdown menu. Click on New, and then Bureau Card. Note that you can also just type
Ctrl N .

section.para:
Move the mouse cursor over the card and the various text items and QSOs Box. Each item in turn is surrounded by an orange dashed rectangle. This indicates the card item that can be selected. With the mouse cursor over the card and not one of the text items or QSOs Box, click the
right mouse button
to display the card context menu.

The image above shows the context menu that is displayed. Click on the Select Highlighted Item menu item. The orange dashed rectangle changes to a blue dashed rectangle to indicate that the card (actually the Background Image) item is selected, and the properties panel changes to contain the properties associated with the Background Item.

Now click the
right mouse button

The image below shows the Select dropdown menu for the card in its current state. The labels for the callsign and name and QTH menu items will match the first ten letters of the callsign and name and QTH field that you set in the user preferences earlier.

section.title: Setting the Background Image
section.para: Select the background using either the Select context menu or the Select dropdown menu. The card will be surrounded by a blue dashed line indicating that it is selected, and the properties panel will contain the background image properties panel, shown in the image below.
Click on the button labeled "..." to open the file open dialog, shown below.

The dialog opens in the hamqsler directory in your documents directory ("My Documents"). The actual directory is determined by a user preferences setting; see the User Preferences chapter for more information.
Navigate to the Samples directory and select the samples.jpg file. The program's main window will now look like this:

section.para: Note the selection rectangle has now extended above and below the top and bottom of the card. The rectangle now outlines the edges of the background image, which does not have the same aspect ratio as the card. Also, in the background image properties panel, the location of the image file is shown below the "..." button.

Move the mouse cursor over the background image. The cursor changes to

To change the size of the size of the image, release the mouse button, then move the mouse cursor to one of the four corners of the image. The cursor will change to either

section.title: Setting Text Items
section.para: Deselect the background image using either the deselect context menu or Select dropdown menu. Select the callsign text item. The text item properties panel, shown below, will now be displayed in the properties panel.
There are a number of properties related to text items; we will look at each of them in turn.

The font dropdown box contains all of the fonts registered with your operating system. The font that is currently selected is the font that you selected in the user preferences earlier in this tutorial. Select a different font. The callsign on the card is now displayed in that font. Notice that only this text changed font, not the other text items.

The text may be displayed in Black, Bold, or Normal weight by selecting the weight from the Font Weight combo box. Italic or Normal style may be selected by checking and unchecking the Italic checkbutton. Try this. For the callsign text, the default is normal style and Black weight.

The size dropdown box contains a number of predefined font sizes (in device independent units which are equal to Â¾ of a point). 72 is the default value for callsigns. You can select any of the sizes directly from the list, or edit the size box to enter any size that you want. When editing the value, use "." as the decimal separator. Try entering a character other than a number or ".". Note the beep emitted by your computer to indicate that you entered an invalid character.Now select the font size that you want.
The color button (the button with the black rectangle) shows the color that the text is displayed in. Click on this button to open the color picker dialog, shown below.

The color picker lets you set a color in a number of different ways. For example, you can select one of the basic or custom colors shown in swatches on the left side of the dialog, or you can select a custom color by clicking in the rainbow on the right side of the dialog and then adjusting the slider to the right of the rainbow to adjust the luminance value. Alternatively you may enter hue, saturation and luminance values or red, green and blue values in the entry boxes below the rainbow. To save as a custom color for later use in the program, click on the "Add to Custom Colors" button.

For this tutorial, a bright orange works best. Set red to 255, green to 128, and blue to 0. Save this as a custom color because we will be using it again, then click the OK button. This closes the color picker dialog. The button in the text item properties panel now displays an orange rectangle, and the callsign text on the card is displayed in orange.

The group box labeled Text holds an edit box containing the text of the callsign. Make some changes to the text and note that the changes are immediately reflected on the card. Reset the text to your callsign.
Ignore the "Macros" button for now.

The Checkboxes group box contains four controls, a checkbutton for adding a checkbox in front of the text, a checkbutton for adding a checkbox after the text, a slider for adjusting the thickness of the lines making up the checkboxes, and a slider to set the size of the checkboxes as a percentage of the height of the text. Adjust each of these controls to see the effect they have. The line thickness and check box ratio sliders only have an effect when at least one of the checkbuttons is checked. Note that the checkboxes are displayed in the same color as the text. Uncheck both checkbuttons.

Move the mouse cursor over the callsign text on the card. The mouse cursor will change to the move cursor. Press and hold the left mouse button, and drag the text to be near the top left corner of the card, then release the mouse button.

Deselect the callsign text and select the text with your name and QTH. Change the color of the text to the same orange color as the callsign. Adjust the postion of the text so that the top of the top line of the text is in line with the top of the callsign text. Position the text so that it is to the right of the callsign.Deselect the text item.
Now look at the salutation text on the card. Note the text is "Thanks for the QSO$. 73, ". The "<S>" characters are a placeholder for a Count Macro. We will look at this macro in a moment.
Select the salutation text item. In the text item properties panel, note that Text group box contains only a Macros button. Click on this button to open the Text and Macros dialog.

The Text and Macros dialog will contain three main group boxes: the groupbox at the top of the dialog, labelled "Static Text", contains a text edit box with the text "Thanks for the QSO", The second main group box, labelled "Count Macro" will be discussed in a moment. The third main group box located at the bottom of the dialog is labelled "Static Text" and contains a text edit box with the text ". 73," in it. The dialog will look like the image below.

The Count Macro group box contains controls for the contents of a Count Macro. A Count Macro displays text based on the number of QSOs rows that are printed in the QSOs Box for cards with no QSOs, and the number of QSOs printed for cards with QSOs. This count macro is set up to print "s" when the QSOs count is greater than one, print nothing when the QSOs count is 1, and to display "<S>" on the card in design mode. Each of these values, and the condition may be modified. See the Macros chapter for more information. We will not make any changes to the count macro or its text in this tutorial.
Change the color of the text to the same orange color as the other text items, and make any adjustments to the position of the text that you would like. Deselect the salutation text item.
Your card should now look like this:

section.title: Setting Qsos Box Properties
section.para: Deselect any selected card item, then select the Qsos Box. The Qsos Box properties panel will be displayed in the properties panel. See the image below for a view of the Qsos Box properties panel. The panel contains many properties, and does not fit fully in the HamQSLer window. The scrollbar to the right of the panel may be used to scroll down to the remaining properties, or you may increase the height of the program's window to show all of the properties.

The text that is displayed in the Qsos Box (e.g. the confirming text (in the top line of the box, the text for each column header, and the text that is displayed in the QSL column, not yet shown on the card) is determined by user preferences and is fixed when the card is first created. See the User Preferences chapter for details on setting these values.

section.title: Setting QSOs and Fields Properties
section.para: Let's look at each property. The Show Manager checkbox when checked adds the text "via ZZZZZZ" to the confirmation line in design mode, and will replace "ZZZZZZ" with the other station's QSL manager if one exists and is included in the Manager column of the QSOs printed on the card. We will look at this later when we select the QSOs to be printed. If no manager exists, the text, including "via" is not printed. Check this checkbox as we will be using it later.

Below the Show Manager checkbox are two radio buttons, one labeled "Show Band Column" and the other labeled "Show Frequency Column". When you create a card, the "Show Band Column" radio button is selected by default. These two radio buttons determine whether the Qsos Box displays a band column or a frequency column. Click the "Show Frequency Column" button. Note that the Band column header has changed to MHz and that the size of the various columns have adjusted themselves.

What happens if you select the Band radio button but your logging program only logs frequency? When the ADIF file containing the QSOs is loaded, or when you manually input QSOs, a band field will be generated for each QSO, with the band corresponding to the band containing the logged frequency.

And what happens if you select the Frequency radio button but the QSO only has a band field and not a frequency field? When each card is printed, a default frequency for that band is substituted. The default frequency for each band may be set in the user preferences.
Make sure that the "Show Band Column" radio button is selected.

The QSL Pse/Tnx checkbox controls the visibility of the QSL column in the Qsos Box. When a card is first created, this checkbox is checked. Uncheck the checkbox; note that the column labeled "QSL" at the left of the Qsos Box has been removed, and the other columns have been resized. The values printed in this column depend on the value of the QSL_RCVD ADIF field for each QSO. If the field contains "Y" indicating that a QSL card has been received confirming this QSO, then the text "Tnx" is printed in the column for that QSO. If the column contains any other value, the text "Pse" is printed in the column. "Tnx" and "Pse" are default values; they may be changed in user preferences.
Make sure that the checkbox is checked before continuing with this tutorial.
The Date Format dropdown box contains three values:

The value selected determines both the text that is displayed in the date column, and the format of the date printed for each QSO. Change to a different value to see the effect on the Qsos Box. Finally, set this value to YYYY-MM-DD for this tutorial.

The Max Qsos control specifies the maximum number of QSOs that may be printed on the card. The control is an editable spinner; you may change values by clicking on the up or down triangles on the right side of the control, or you may directly edit the value. Valid values are between 1 and 15. Try multiple values to see how the Qsos Box changes.
The default value when you create a new card is 4. There is no way to change this default.
Finally, set this value to 2.

section.title: Setting Line and Text Properties
section.para: There are three color buttons. Each button opens the color picker dialog to allow you to select a color. The three colors control the color of the lines and text in the Qsos Box, the color of the callsign in the confirming text, and the color of the manager in the confirming text. Set the line and text color to orange (red=255, green=128, blue=0), and set the manager color to green (red=0, green=255, blue=0). The orange text is a bit hard to read but we will fix that in a moment.

The Font Size dropdown box contains values between 8.0 and 14.0. This sets the size of the font in the QSOs Box. Try different values. For the 2 QSOs that we have set as the maximum, a value of 12.0 points is good. Smaller values will be needed when you select a large Max QSOs value; otherwise the box would not fit on the card.

The Font dropdown box allows you to select the font that the text in the Qsos Box is displayed and printed in. The initial font selected in the dropdown box is the font that you specified as the default QSOs Box font in the User Preferences earlier. Select a few different fonts and notice how the height of the Qsos Box changes. The actual height of a line of text in each font will be different, even though the font size has not changed.
Set the font to a value that looks good to you.

section.title: Setting Qsos Box Background Properties
section.para: These properties control the color and the opacity (opposite of transparency) of the background of the Qsos Box.

Click on the Color button to display the color picker dialog. This dialog may be used to change the color of the background of the Qsos Box. Note that any change you make is not visible. We will correct that in a moment.
The opacity slider adjusts the opacity (1 - transparency) of the background. Adjust the slider to select values between 0 and 100% to see the effect on the Qsos Box.

When you have finished playing, set the color to black (red=0, green=0, blue=0), and set the opacity to 30%. Note that the orange text in the Qsos Box is now much more visible, and that a considerable amount of the detail in the background image shows through.

section.title: Adjusting the Position of the Qsos Box
section.para:
Move the mouse cursor over the Qsos Box. The cursor will change to
. This cursor indicates that you can only adjust the Qsos Box vertically and not horizontally. Press the left mouse button and drag the Qsos Box. When you are done, release the mouse button. For this card, positioning the Qsos Box anywhere that is not over a text item will work.
Deselect the Qsos Box. Your card should look similar to the image below:

section.title: Saving the Card
section.para: Select the Save Card As... menu item from the Cards dropdown menu. This opens the File Save dialog, shown in the image below:

Note that the dialog opens in the hamqsler directory. Select the Samples directory; enter the file name "sample" in the Name edit box near the top of the dialog, and click the Save button. The card will be saved with the name "sample.qslx".
The text on the tab will in the main window will change from "New Card*" to "sample.qslx".
In the future, this card may be opened using the Open Card... menu item in the Cards dropdown menu.
We are now done designing the card, so let's load an ADIF file containing some QSOs to select for printing.

section.title: Selecting QSOs to Print on the Card
section.para: Click on the QSOs tab. Select Import QSOs... from the QSOs dropdown menu. This opens the File Open dialog in the hamqsler directory. Select the Samples directory, and open the file "sample.adi". The program main window should look like this:

section.title: Selecting QSOs Sort Order
section.para: The QSOs properties panel is shown below.

As noted here, when an ADIF file is first imported, the QSOs are sorted by date and time. QSOs may also be sorted by manager and callsign, and by bureau followed by manager and callsign. Select each of the sort order radio buttons and note how the order of the QSOs changes in the QSOs panel.

With the Bureau radio button set, note that all QSOs with the Send Via column set to "Bureau" are sorted to the top of the QSOs panel, followed by QSOs whose Send Via is set to Direct. The values in the Send Via column are set according to the values of the QSL_SENT_VIA field in ADIF records as follows:
Even though some QSOs may have a value of Electronic or Manager in the Send Via column, it is still possible to include these QSOs on cards that you print.
Leave the Bureau radio button selected.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Band
section.para: Note that the checkboxes in the Include column for all QSOs are checked to indicate that all QSOs will be printed on cards.
In the QSOs properties panel, click on the Band tab. The expanded widget looks like this:
Uncheck the 40m checkbox. Note that the checkbox in the Include column of the third QSO is now unchecked; this is the only QSO that took place on the 40m band.
Leave this unchecked.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Mode
section.para: Click on the Mode tab; it looks like the image below.
Deselect the CW checkbox. All QSOs in the CW mode are deselected. Reselect the CW mode checkbox. Again all QSOs except the QSO on 40m are selected.
Leave all modes selected.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by Date and Time
section.para: Click on the Date/Time tab. The tab contents look like this:

The start date and time fields contain the date and time of the earliest QSO in the QSOs panel. The end date and time correspond to the date and time of the latest QSO. Change the start date to "20021201". Note that the QSOs whose start date occur before this date are now deselected. Similarly, you could change the start time and the end date and time to deselect other QSOs.
Now click the Reset button. The start and end dates are reset to the dates and times of the earliest and latest QSOs.

section.title: Selecting QSOs by QSL Statuses
section.para: The image below shows the content of the QSL Status tab. It contains three sections, one for Rcvd statuses, one for Sent statuses, and one for Sent Via statuses.
Select various statuses to see the QSOs that are selected and deselected. When you are finished, make sure that all checkboxes are checked.

section.title: Selecting Individual QSOs
section.para: You may select individual QSOs by checking and unchecking the checkboxes in the Include column. To do this, you must click on the checkbox itself. If you click anywhere else on the QSO, the QSO is selected. this is not what you want at this time.
It is also possible to check and uncheck all QSOs at once or multiple QSOs at a time. That is covered in the chapter titled Working With QSOs.
Before proceeding, make sure that only the third QSO is deselected.

section.title: Default Printer and Print Options Properties
section.para: Click on the tab labeled "sample.qslx" to redisplay the card that you designed earlier.
Select the Print Cards... menu item from the Cards dropdown menu. This opens the Print dialog shown below.

Select the printer you would use for printing the cards, and then click the "Preferences" button to set printing preferences such as print quality and paper size. For now, select a paper size of either letter or A4. Do not set Portrait or Landscape mode because this setting is overridden later. Now click the OK button to close the Printing Preferences dialog.
Click the "Print" button to close the Print dialog and open the Print Settings dialog, shown below.

The card layout group box on the left of the dialog allows you to select how the cards are printed on the page. Depending on the size of the paper you selected in the Printing Preferences dialog and the size of the cards you will be printing, there will be up to six choices. The layouts shown in the figure above are for bureau sized cards on letter sized (8Â½ by 11 inch) paper. The cards are shown in white with a blue edge and the paper or cardstock is shown in light pink so you can see how the cards are layed out. For this tutorial, select the layout at the top left.
The Options group box on the right of the Print Settings dialog controls certain print options:
The Print Card Outlines checkbox controls whether a black line is printed around the edges of each card. Printing the card outline makes it easier to cut the cards out of the cardstock.

If the number of cards to be printed does not exactly equal the number of pages to be printed multiplied by the number of cards per page, then a portion of the last page would be wasted. In this tutorial for example, four cards would be printed at three cards per page. In order not to waste a portion of the cardstock, you may print "blank" cards to fill the rest of the page. These blank cards contain no QSO information; you may enter this information using a pen at a later time. Printing or not printing these blank cards is controlled by the Fill Last Page With Blank Cards checkbox.

Unless you selected a borderless page size, then your printer will not print to the edge of the cardstock, but will leave margins of different sizes around the edges of the cardstock when you print the cards. Because you will be printing multiple cards per page, the cards would have unequal, unprinted margins along one or more sides of each card. To create equal sized margins around the edges of each card, check the Set Card Margins to Printer Page Margins checkbox. Depending on card layout that you choose, this checkbox may be checked or unchecked. For this tutorial, make sure that this checkbox is checked.

Please note: if you are using a printer that does not provide its margin information, this checkbox will be unchecked and disabled, so you will not be able to check it. After you clicked the "Print" button on the Print dialog, a message dialog will have been displayed to inform you of this.
To print the cards you would click the "Print" button. Since you probably do not want to waste the paper and ink on this first card, click the "Preview" button. This opens the print preview dialog.

There is a toolbar at the top of the dialog. The buttons on this toolbar allow you to control the magnification of each page and to specify whether you want to display one or two pages at a time. A scrollbar on the right side of the dialog allows you to scroll through the various pages to be printed.

On the first page, the first card contains the two QSOs to VA3JNO with VA3HJ as the manager. The second card contains a single QSO with VA3JNO, and the third card contains a single QSO with 5C5CW. If the maximum number of QSOs on a card had been set to 1, only a single QSO would have been printed on each card.

Note that on the cards with one QSO, the confirming text in the QSOs Box is "Confirming 2-Way QSO with ...", and the salutation text is "Thanks for the QSO. 73,". On the card with two QSOs the texts are "Confirming 2-Way QSOs with..." and "Thanks for the QSOs. 73,". The inclusion and exclusion of the "s" on "QSO" is controlled by a Count Macro. See Macros for more information.

Now view the second page of cards. The first card is for the QSO with CG3JNO, and the last two cards contain a QSOs Box with two empty lines. These cards are printed because you checked the "Fill Last Page With Blank Cards" checkbox.
Every card is surrounded by a black line on all sides because you checked the "Print Card Outlines" checkbox.
Close the print preview dialog. Go back and try the various print options settings combinations to see the effect that each setting has.

If, after viewing the pages to be printed in the Print Preview dialog, you want to print the pages, you must close the dialog and restart the print process, clicking the Print button on the Print Settings dialog. It is not possible to print from the Print Preview dialog.

section.title: Concluding the Tutorial
section.para: You have now concluded this tutorial, but you have only scratched the surface of the capabilities of HamQSLer. Be sure to read the remaining chapters in this user manual as they contain more information on every aspect of the program and also contain many helpful hints and suggestions to get the most out of HamQSLer.

chapter.title: Program Initialization and the Splash Screen

section.title: Introduction to Macros
section.para: Macros add a powerful feature to HamQSLer by providing active text. For every macro there is text that is displayed on the card in design view, and text that is inserted when the cards are printed. These macros may be used in any text item and also in the confirming text user preference. If you followed the Getting Started Tutorial, you got your first glimpse of Count Macro.
This discussion will focus on macros used in text items; using macros in the confirming text user preference are similar to macros within the Text and Macros dialog which you will see shortly.

The image below shows the text area in a text item properties panel. If there are no macros used in the text item, then this is what you will see: a text box for editing the static text, and a button labeled "Macros". If there are macros being used in the text item, then only the button is visible.

figure.title: Static Text Only in Text Item Properties

section.para: Clicking the button opens the Text and Macros dialog, shown with static text only, in the image below.

figure.title: Static Text Only in the Text and Macros Dialog

section.para: To add a macro, place the mouse cursor over the colored rectangle that contains the "Static Text" and click the right mouse button to bring up the macros context menu, shown below.
The context menu permits you to add a macro either before or after the static text or macro colored rectangle you opened the context menu over. There are a few things to notice:

simplelist.member: The Delete menu item cannot be selected when only one static text or macro exists.
Static text items cannot be inserted next to another static text item, only next to macros.

section.para: The image below shows the dialog after a Manager Macro has been inserted after the static text item, and all expanders have been expanded.

figure.title: Static Text and Manager Macro in Text and Macros Dialog

section.para: Every macro has a section called "Design Text". This is the text that is displayed on the card in design mode. In the Getting Started Tutorial, this is the "<S>" in both the confirming text in the QSOs Box and in the salutation text item. Other sections are specific to the macros. At print time, the Manager Macro will place the contents of the Manager field for the QSO on the card, or the No Manager Text if the Manager field is empty. Any of these fields may be blank.

Macros may be inserted inside macros anywhere that a static text field is allowed. For example, you could add a macro inside the Design Text or No Manager Text fields of the Manager Macro, but you could not add another macro at the same level as the Design Text or No Manager Text sections. While macros may theoretically be added to any depth, you should take great care with this facility as keeping track of the macro level becomes increasingly difficult as macros are added to greater depths.
The remaining sections in this chapter describe each macro.

section.title: ADIF Macro
section.para: An ADIF Macro prints the contents of an ADIF field on a card if the field exists and is not an empty string; otherwise, it prints user specified text. The image below shows a view of the ADIF Macro as it would first appear after adding in the Text and Macros dialog.

The contents of an ADIF field may change from one QSO to the next. Because of this, you will normally want to print a different card every time the contents of the ADIF field changes. Checking the "Separate Cards By This ADIF Field" checkbox will do this; if you do not check this checkbox, then the contents of the ADIF field from the first QSO that is printed on the card will be added to the card.

Add the name of the ADIF field for this macro to the ADIF Field text box. Standard ADIF fields are defined in the ADIF standard, available at http://www.adif.org. Be sure to select the version of the standard that corresponds to the version specified by your logging application. In addition to the fields defined in the standard, your logger may also export application specific fields. See the documentation for your logger for these fields.
The field name is not case sensitive; for example, "CALL", "call", and "CalL" are all valid.
The No Field Text section contains the text that would be printed if either the ADIF field does not exist for the QSOs, or the value of the field is an empty string.

tip.para: Do you operate using a number of different callsigns? If you do and your exported ADIF file contains the STATION_CALLSIGN field, then you could replace the static callsign text item with an ADIF Macro for the STATION_CALLSIGN. Be sure to check the "Separate Cards By This ADIF Field" checkbox. Then a single card can be used for every one of your callsigns.

QSL bureaus prefer that the callsign of the station that is to receive a QSL card be written in the upper right or left corner of the back or front of the card. You could do this by adding a new text item, positioning it appropriately, and including text such as "To: " as well as an ADIF macro for the CALL field.

HamQSLer does not easily support printing this on the opposite side of the card from other text and the QSOs Box, but if you properly design your card, it can be placed on the same side as these items and still be very visible to the sorters at the QSL bureaus.

You could customize the confirming text in the QSOs Box or the salutation text item to contain mode information. For example, your salutation could be "Thanks for the CW QSOs. 73, " for CW QSOs and so forth.

section.title: ADIF Exists Macro
section.para: The ADIF Exists Macro prints user specified text if the ADIF field exists for a QSO and its contents are not an empty string, and prints a different user specified text if the field either does not exist or the field contents are empty. The image below shows a view of the ADIF Exists Macro.
This image shows the various sections as they would be immediately after the macro has been added to the Text and Macros dialog.

Checking the "Separate Cards By This ADIF Field Exists" checkbox will cause a new QSL card to be printed every time that consecutive QSOs have and have not included this ADIF field, or the field contents are not empty.

Add the name of the ADIF field for this macro to the ADIF Field text box. Standard ADIF fields are defined in the ADIF standard, available at http://www.adif.org. Be sure to select the version of the standard that corresponds to the version specified by your logging application. In addition to the fields defined in the standard, your logger may also export application specific fields. See the documentation for your logger for these fields.
The field name is not case sensitive; for example, "CALL", "call", and "CalL" are all valid.
Enter the text that you want to appear on the card in design view in the Design Text edit box.
Enter the text that you want displayed if the ADIF field exists in the Field Exists Text section.
Enter the text that you want displayed if the ADIF field doesn't exist in the Field Doesn't Exist Text section.

tip.para: If you are a contester, you could use this macro to modify the salutation to say "Thanks for the contest QSOs. 73, " for cards for your contest QSOs and not include the "contest" word for non-contest QSOs.

section.title: Count Macro
section.para: The Count Macro specifies text that is to be printed when the condition is met and text that is printed when the condition is not met. When a card with QSOs in the QSOs Box is printed, the condition is tested against the number of QSOs being printed in the QSOs Box. If a blank card (i.e. a card without QSOs) is printed, the condition is tested against the max QSOs count for the QSOs Box. This matches the number of blank rows printed on the card.
The image below shows a view of the Count Macro. This image shows the various sections as they would be immediately after the macro has been added to the Text and Macros dialog.
The Condition radio buttons set the test that is to be performed against the Condition Value. The conditions are:
The Condition Value is the number of QSOs or the max QSOs value for the QSOs Box. This value may be set to any value between 1 and 15, and matches the range of values allowed for max QSOs.
Enter the text you want to be displayed on the card in design mode in the Design Text section.

Enter the text that is to be printed when the condition is met in the True Text section. This is the "<S>" text that is displayed in the confirming text and the salutation text as set in the original user preferences.
Enter the text that is to be printed when the condition is not met in the False Text section.
You may reverse conditions by reversing the True Text and False Text texts.

tip.para: The confirming text in the QSOs Box and the salutation text defined in the original user preferences (set when you start HamQSLer for the first time) each contain a Count Macro. As used there, the design text is "<S>", "s" is printed when the number of QSOs (or the max QSOs count for blank cards) is greater than 1 and no text is printed when the number of QSOs is 1.
It would appear that the use of this macro is limited to cases such as this.

section.title: Manager Macro
section.para: The Manager Macro prints the contents of the Manager column in the QSOs tab if this field is a valid callsign, and prints user defined text if the manager's callsign is not valid.
The image below shows the various sections as they would be immediately after the macro has been added to the Text and Macros dialog.
Enter the text you want displayed on the card in design mode into the Design Text section.
Enter the text you want printed when there is no valid manager in the No Manager Text section.
See the Manager Exists Macro section, below, for one use of this macro.

section.title: Manager Exists Macro
section.para: The Manager Exists Macro prints one set of user defined text if the manager field exists and its contents are a valid callsign, and another set of user defined text if the field is empty or does not contain a valid callsign.
The image below shows the various sections as they would be immediately after the macro has been added to the Text and Macros dialog.
Enter the text that you want to be displayed in card design mode in the Design Text section.
Enter the text that you want printed when the manager field exists and is a valid callsign in the Exists Text section.
Enter the text that you want printed on the card when the manager field does not exist, or its contents is not a valid callsign.

tip.para: QSL bureaus prefer that the callsign of the station that is to receive a QSL card be written in the upper right or left corner of the back or front of the card. You could do this by adding a new text item, positioning it appropriately, and including text such as "To: " or "Via: " as well as a Manager Exists Macro for the manager field. In the Exists Text section, add a Manager Macro so that the callsign of the manager is printed after the "To: " or "Via: " text.

HamQSLer does not easily support printing this on the opposite side of the card from other text and the QSOs Box, but if you properly design your card, it can be placed on the same side as these items and still be very visible to the sorters at the QSL bureaus.

section.title: Saving HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been created, it may be saved to be loaded and used at a future time. To do this, select the Cards->File Save or Cards->File Save As... menu items. File Save is only available if the card has previously been saved because the program must know the directory in which you want to save the card.
When you select the Card Save As... menu item, the File Save dialog, shown below, is displayed.

The dialog opens with the default directory set to your hamqsler folder. Navigate to the folder where you want to save the card file, then click on the Save button. The card file will be saved and the dialog will close.

section.title: Loading HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been saved, it can be loaded at a later time by selecting the Cards->Open Card... menu item. This displays the File Open dialog with the default directory set to your hamqsler folder. See the image below:
The dropdown box circled in red near the bottom right of the dialog lets you select the type of card to open. It defaults to HamQSLer cards, which have an extension of ".qslx".
Navigate to the directory containing the card file you want to open, and either click on the file and then the Open button, or double-click on the file.

tip.para: Keep all of your card related files (card files, images, logos, etc.) in the hamqsler directory or create subdirectories for each file type. That way, all of the files needed for your cards are located in one place so they are easy to back up and to move to another location.

In the past, as Microsoft released new versions of Windows, they sometimes changed the location of the My Directories folder. This occurred, for example, when Windows Vista was released, and people who upgraded from Windows XP had problems with hard-coded paths.

If you want to reload the saved card or cards every time you restart the program, check the "Reload Card Files on Startup" checkbox in the User Preferences. See the User Preferences chapter for more information.

section.title: Loading QslDesignAndPrint Card Files
section.para: Card files that were created with QslDesignAndPrint may be loaded into HamQSLer. To do this, select the Cards->Open Card... menu item. Then select the QslDnP Card type from the dropdown box circled in red in the figure above.
Navigate to the directory containing the card file you want to open, and either click on the file and then the Open button, or double-click on the file.

caution.para: This feature is deprecated and will be removed in the future. Load all of your QslDesignAndPrint cards into HamQSLer and then save them using the Cards->Save As... menu item. Be sure to save the new cards in the hamqsler folder.

When you load a QslDesignAndPrint card into HamQSLer, the program marks the card as modified. If you attempt to close the program before you have saved the card, you will get a message asking if you want to save the file. If you answer Yes, then the file is saved in the same directory as the card file was loaded from. You are not given the option of saving the file in a different directory.
